docs.text: capsule : this is a harrowing look at a rarely dramatized chapter of wwii , life in a japanese prison camp .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: to end all wars is a moving film about the struggle of prisoners to retain their humanity and their dignity .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the somewhat religious interpretation may not be to everyone's taste .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: more than any other people the japanese seem capable of acting with one goal and not letting any other consideration get in their way .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: this may be a holdover from the code of bushido when loyalty to ones master was the only law .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: during world war ii , of course , the one goal was winning the war .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: this led them to do some very inhuman things in pursuit of that goal .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: when the japanese had captured prisoners , they were very much treated in whatever way would be optimum for achieving the one goal .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: minimum resources were to be spent in maintaining prisoners in keeping with maximal positive output .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: while the germans , not known for their kindness in those days , had a 6% mortality rate among captured prisoners of war , the mortality rate of japanese prisoners of war was 27% .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the best thing for the war effort was working prisoners nearly to death on the thailand to burma railroad .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: that railroad was needed if japan was to attack india as it planned to do .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the best thing for the effort was not to waste much food on the prisoners so short and amazingly wretched food was the order of the day .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: and just being in the jungle without proper medical aid took its toll .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: in the public mind japan has never been held as accountable for war atrocities as was germany .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: filmmakers have been reticent to tell the story , perhaps for fear of offending the japanese .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: there are comparatively few films about the japanese pow camps .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: certainly there was david lean's the bridge on the river kwai .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: there were some low-budget british exploitation films and that was about it .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: then there were tv series " a town like alice " and " tenko . "
docs.label: positive

docs.text: lest the experience be forgotten we have a new film to end all wars directed by david cunningham and written by brian godawa .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it is based on the account of ernest gordan who survived the horror of that world war ii prison camp and went on to become for 26 years the dean of the chapel at princeton university .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the film while realistic shows the conditions in the camp as being considerably more brutal and sadistic than bridge on the river kwai portrayed them .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the story opens with six or so soldiers being marched into the prison camp only to be immediately placed in front of a firing squad .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it turns out to be a grim joke , one of many that the sadistic japanese play to amuse themselves .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: beating and torture are commonplace events .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: men already imprisoned tell the new arrivals to enjoy the last of their health ; it will not last long with parasites and disease almost inevitable .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: however , unlike as in kwai , the prisoners want to avoid going to the hospital , called by the prisoners the death house .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: so goes a war within a war with the prisoners trying to maintain their humanity and with the japanese trying to make them interchangeable and highly expendable cogs in a rail-laying machine .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: this is more than just a battle of who will win the war but a battle of ideologies .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the japanese believe that the individual is nothing , that conformity to group's norms is all that gives a life meaning .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: conformity is purpose .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: before the film is over there will be some surprising revelations about the character of the prisoners and the character of those running the camp .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: if this story showed nothing but sadism from the japanese it would be one kind of story .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: if the british ( with one american , by the way ) and the japanese learned to respect each other it would be another kind of story .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it is neither .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it is a stirring and believable account of camp life .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the color has been distorted in the film to give a washed out yellow .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: this serves a double purpose for cunningham .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it gives an effect of technicolor film that has been left in heat .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it also creates a distancing effect .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the only touch that seems a little out of place is the use of gaelic music .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: this is a powerful and philosophical view of the prison camp experience .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: i rate it a 9 on the 0 to 10 scale and a +3 on the -4 to +4 scale .
docs.label: positive
